title: 109_s2165
content: The "Kendell Frederick Citizenship Assistance Act" waives the fingerprint requirement for members of the Armed Forces. The "Kendell Frederick Citizenship Assistance Act" waives the fingerprint requirement for members of the Armed Forces enlisting under certain conditions for naturalization. The Secretary of Defense establishes Citizenship Advocates at Military Entry Processing Stations to assist Armed Forces members with the naturalization process. Written materials describing naturalization are provided to non-citizen enlistees, and a toll-free hotline is available for information on naturalization for Armed Forces members and their families. The Department of Homeland Security operates a telephone service for naturalization under the Immigration and Nationality Act, ensuring specialized training for employees assisting Armed Forces members and their families. Quality control measures are in place to monitor information accuracy regularly. The accuracy and quality of information provided by employees operating the telephone service for naturalization under the Immigration and Nationality Act are monitored regularly. SEC. 4. The Secretary of Homeland Security must update naturalization application forms, instructions, guidebooks, and the website within 30 days of any modifications to laws or regulations related to naturalization. SEC. 5. Reports. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report on the adjudication process for naturalization applications within 120 days of the enactment of the Act. The report will cover the methods used by the Secretary of Homeland Security and the Secretary of Defense in handling applications and the effectiveness of the chain of authority. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on the implementation of the Act by the Secretary of Homeland Security and the Secretary of Defense, focusing on the use of technology to improve the efficiency of the naturalization process for members of the Armed Forces. A report on this study is due within 180 days. The Comptroller General will submit a report to the appropriate congressional committees within 180 days with recommendations for improving the implementation of the Act by the Secretary of Homeland Security or the Secretary of Defense. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific committees in the Senate and House of Representatives.
